description:
On July 10, 2001, the Mumbai Police Cyber Crime Cell website was hacked and defaced with abusive content accusing the police of inefficiency. The attackers, identified as Indian hackers including Anand Khare (alias Dr. Neukar), exploited weakly protected web infrastructure. Following the defacement, Mumbai Police investigated and arrested suspects, including Khare and others linked to the G-13 Hackers Force. This incident caused fear in the local hacker community and led to allegations of police brutality during interrogations.

Key details:
- Target: Mumbai Police Cyber Crime Cell (websites: www.cybercellbombaycity.com and www.ccicbombay.com)
- Actors: Indian hackers (Dr. Neukar and associates)
- Method: Web server compromise from a cyber cafe, traced via IP
- Consequence: Public embarrassment for law enforcement, subsequent arrests, up to 3 years imprisonment under IT Act

organization: Multiple Indian IIS web servers (corporates, ISPs, academic sites)
attackMethod: Remote buffer overflow exploit on Microsoft IIS
impact: Widespread infections, defaced IIS websites, and service disruptions in India
description:
Starting July 13, 2001, the Code Red worm began infecting Microsoft IIS web servers worldwide, including in India. The worm exploited a buffer overflow vulnerability (CVE-2001-0500) and spread rapidly by scanning random IPs. In India, numerous IIS servers belonging to corporates, ISPs, and academic institutions were infected, causing website defacements (e.g., 'Hacked by Chinese') and major service disruptions. It highlighted the global nature of worm threats and prompted emergency patching.

Key details:
- Exploit: IIS Indexing Service vulnerability
- Impact in India: Website defacements, network slowdowns, part of global havoc
- Consequence: Emergency patching and heightened awareness of global worms in India

In early August 2001, a variant called Code Red II emerged. While it exploited the same IIS vulnerability as Code Red, it also installed a backdoor on compromised systems. Indian IIS servers were again affected, with reports of reinfections and persistent compromises due to delayed patching. This variant was more dangerous as it enabled remote access.

Key details:
- Exploit: Same IIS flaw as Code Red
- Difference: Backdoor installation for remote access
- Impact in India: IIS servers at risk of long-term compromise, part of global spread

On September 18, 2001, the Nimda worm spread globally within hours, using multiple propagation methods: email (e.g., readme.exe attachment), compromised websites, network shares, and unpatched IIS exploits. In India, corporates, ISPs, and academic networks reported major disruptions including clogged email servers, defaced websites, and widespread downtime. Reports varied on severity, with some noting limited impact but others describing havoc.

Key details:
- Methods: Email, websites, shares, exploits
- Impact in India: Significant cleanup required across organizations
- Consequence: Proved how multi-vector worms could cripple Indian networks rapidly

In late 2001, individuals including a former ISRO scientist sent threatening emails to the Department of Atomic Energy (DAE), claiming affiliation with Lashkar-e-Toiba and threatening attacks on Indian installations. Mumbai Police arrested the suspects on October 31, 2001, charging them with sedition and cybercrimes. The accused ran a firm teaching hacking and used it for extortion. Bail was denied on November 17, 2001. This was one of the earliest high-profile Indian cases combining cybercrime with national security concerns. Note: The exact date of November 22 may refer to a court proceeding or article publication; the email was sent September 21, arrests October 31.

Key details:
- Target: Department of Atomic Energy
- Actors: Former ISRO scientist I.S. Mudaliar and associate Umang Dave
- Method: Threatening emails
- Consequence: Arrests, sedition charges (up to life imprisonment), reputational impact
